thread.title: Having a deep bench will be the only way LSU goes deep in the NCAA tournament: Ron Higgins
thread.title_full: Having a deep bench will be the only way LSU goes deep in the NCAA tournament: Ron Higgins | NOLA.com

author: Ron Higgins, NOLA.com | The Times-Picayune
title: Having a deep bench will be the only way LSU goes deep in the NCAA tournament: Ron Higgins
text:
There was an amazing sight Wednesday afternoon in an almost-empty Pete Maravich Assembly Center.
More than 20 NBA scouts sat at courtside to watch an LSU pre-season basketball practice on day two of the Tigers' NBA pro days in which 28 of the league's 30 teams sent scouts.
When fourth-year LSU coach Johnny Jones took over the program, the talent cupboard was left so bare by his predecessor – the surly Trent Johnson – that Jones could have offered to fly scouts to Baton Rouge on private jets to watch practice and they wouldn't have wasted their time.
But with freshman phenom Ben Simmons, projected as the No. 1 pick in next year's NBA Draft, versatile point guard Tim Quarterman, feisty and relentless swingman Keith Hornsby, rough and ready transfer forward Craig Victor and long-range gunning freshman guard Antonio Blakeney, there was much eye candy for the scouts to observe on the Tigers' potentially outstanding team.
The key words are "potentially" and "team."
"The funny thing is everybody is so happy and excited about the team, but we really haven't done anything yet," said Simmons, the exceedingly mature 19-year old who calmly handled a barrage of media day questions before the Tigers showed their stuff to the scouts.
Until the regular season starts Nov. 13 vs. McNeese and the Tigers face teams of consequence like Marquette and Arizona State or North Carolina State Nov. 23-24 in the Barclays Classic in Brooklyn, the LSU's potential will remain simply potential.
If the Tigers hope to mount a serious NCAA tournament run, they understand that it must be done as a complete team, with a viable deep bench that has the talent not just to maintain but also extend leads.
The most remarkable thing about last year's Tigers is they won 22 games and made a one-game NCAA tournament appearance with four members of the starting five averaging 33 or more minutes and a bench that barely played.
Why didn't the Tigers ever develop any sort of bench a year ago? Because Jones was under pressure to win and get a NCAA tourney bid, so he and his team had virtually no margin of error, especially with a few nagging early injuries.
"When you play a tough schedule, it's demanding and the games are close and each possession is so important, you don't rotate your bench as much," Jones said. "This year we're hoping with some of the experience we had from our bench guys, along with this talented group of freshmen, we can manage the minutes better. The earlier we can develop a bench, the quicker we can lower minutes (for starters) to the 27 to 30 minutes range."
Even for someone like Hornsby, who has Forrest Gump-like coast-to-coast stamina, playing without the safety net of a reliable bench last season was more mentally than physically taxing.
"When you play a lot of minutes," said Hornsby, who averaged a team-leading 35.3 minutes per game, which was also second in the SEC, "subconsciously you're going to have the foul count in your head. Nobody wants to be out of the game with two fouls at the 15-minute mark in the first half. You have to find a way to play super aggressively and not make any stupid fouls."
Because the Tigers' depth didn't often didn't go past one guard and maybe one inside player, almost all their conference games took a predictable track. If LSU stayed out of foul trouble, got off to fast starts and maintained double digit leads through the first half, it usually had enough fouls to give and plenty of fuel in the tank in the second half to hold on for wins.
But when that didn't happen. . .
Also, at the end of last season, it was clear Tigers' starters like All-SEC forward Jordan Mickey were running on fumes. His production dramatically nosedived in the last two weeks of the season and in the postseason.
"We wore our starters down toward the end of the year," LSU backup point guard Josh Gray said. "But it's going to be better this year, because we have more depth."
Any depth would be an improvement. But from watching the Tigers go through their paces before the scouts, they are light years ahead of last season with a greater number of capable versatile bodies.
"When we go to the bench, there's no dropoff, especially all the guards (six) that we have," Quarterman said. "All of us have different types of games. It will be hard for teams to scout us."
Hornsby noted that LSU's post players have improved. They are all returnees from last year's team including Victor, who sat out the spring semester but practiced with the team after transferring from Arizona.
"They've shown a new fire that I hadn't seen in them since I've been here," Hornsby said. "It's almost like they heard that they are really needed right now in their roles, and they've taken to that. They're playing with a new edge and confidence."
One reason that's happening, according to Victor, is the raised talent level has naturally increased practice intensity.
"We have a team full of competitive spirit, especially with the incoming freshmen," Victor said. "Everybody has improved and everybody wants to win. We all realize the only way to get better is to make each other better. The more we push each other, the better this team will be."
On LSU's five-game exhibition trip to Australia in early August, only Simmons averaged more than 30 minutes (35.5) per game. Three other players who started the majority of the games – Quarterman, Hornsby and Blakeney – were in the 25 to 29-minute range.
The top four bench players averaged between 11.3 (forward Brian Bridgewater) and 14.0 (Aaron Epps) minutes.
"The way Coach Jones played us in Australia, it shows he trusts the bench," Bridgewater said.
That's cool. But let's check back on that trust once SEC play starts in January.
